newsitem.title: JAPAN: Dlr off highs vs yen after rising on Japan output.
newsitem.headline: Dlr off highs vs yen after rising on Japan output.

text.p: 0624 GMT TRADED HIGH/LOW AS OF 0600 GMT
The dollar was off its highs against the yen by late afternoon Tokyo on Wednesday, after briefly rising on Japan's industrial output data for June.

Output fell a preliminary 3.1 percent month-on-month on a seasonally adjusted basis. Economists had forecast on average a fall of 2.8 percent. Forecasts ranged from a fall of 1.2 percent to fall of a 4.0 percent.
The dollar touched a high of 118.60 yen after the output data was released, with stop-loss buying triggered around 118.55 yen, traders said.
However, the greenback eased quickly on profit taking, they said.
A trust bank trader said operators see the area near 119 yen as a good level to take profits in the near term.
However, traders said they still expect the dollar to eventually test key resistance at 119 yen, which represents the 50-percent retracement of the 1997 high/low between 126.47 and 110.62.
Japan's industrial output data was encouraging for dollar bulls focusing on the discrepancy between the economic growth of Japan and the United States, a trader at a city bank said.
"At the moment, people are looking at the strength of the U.S. economy and are being encouraged to buy dollars," he said.
However, worries about the U.S.-Japan trade friction might resurface if the greenback continues to rise towards 120 yen, traders said.
Makoto Utsumi, a former Japanese vice finance minister, said on Tuesday that a range of 110 to 120 yen to the dollar is not a problem but a yen weaker than 125 yen would be excessive.
Traders expect Japanese financial authorities to start talking down the dollar if it rises above 120 yen as such a level could fuel concerns about the U.S.-Japan trade imbalance.

"Japan's financial authorities have been quiet despite the recent rise in the dollar versus the yen, but market participants are becoming more cautious about possible comments from them," said a trader at another city bank.

Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka said on Tuesday that the current yen exchange rate is moving within normal market fluctuations. He added that one should not overly emphasise temporary market moves.
Traders said dollar selling by Japanese exporters was not so aggressive.
"Exporters appeared quite relaxed, seeing no urgent need to sell dollars aggressively now," said a trust bank trader.
Earlier, the Australian dollar fell after an interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), but recovered later on short covering and talk of buying by a Chinese bank.
The RBA said on Wednesday that it had cut its official cash rate by 50 basis points to 5.0 percent.
The Aussie stood at around $0.7470/75 at 0725 GMT after falling as low as around $0.7395 in early trade.
Singapore dealers said the dollar was taking a breather against the mark but it had remained well supported around 1.8250 marks and was likely to head higher after some consolidation.
"The dollar's poised to retest 1.85 marks again and in the longer term, it should go up to 1.92," said a European bank dealer in Singapore.
The dollar closed at 118.35/40 yen and 1.8375/85 marks in New York on Tuesday.
-- Sonali Desai, Singapore newsroom +65-8703080
-- Kanta Watanabe, Tokyo Treasury Desk +81-3-3432-9780
